title: Tony Blair accuses Tories of agreeing £20million payments to Guantanamo Bay detainees - Number 10 declines to comment
text:
Tony Blair accuses Tories of agreeing £20million payments to Guantanamo Bay detainees - Number 10 declines to comment Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair Credit: Carl Court/Getty Images Christopher Hope , Chief Political Correspondent 22 February 2017 • 1:19pm 
A major political row has broken out over £20million compensation payments made to former British Guantanamo Bay detainees after former Labour Prime Minister Tony Blair said the Tories had agreed the sums. 
Theresa May, the Prime Minister, is already under pressure to explain why a British Islamic State fighter who carried out a suicide bombing in Iraq travelled to Syria in 2014 to fight with the so-called Islamic State when she was home secretary. 
Jamal al-Harith, a Muslim convert born Ronald Fiddler who detonated a car bomb at an Iraqi army base near Mosul, was released from the US detention camp in 2004 and successfully claimed £1million compensation after saying British agents knew or were complicit in his mistreatment. Jamal al-Harith Credit: Universal News & Sport 
I n all an estimated £20million was paid to 16 British citizens and residents who were held at the camp. 
In a statement from Mr Blair’s office, he said: “It is correct that Jamal al-Harith was released from Guantanamo Bay at the request of the British Government in 2004.” 
He added: “He was not paid compensation by my Government. The compensation was agreed in 2010 by the Conservative Government.” Jamal al-Harith (AKA Jamal Udeen) Credit: BANARAS KHAN 
N umber 10 declined to comment on the compensation payments, whether they were necessary, whether they would be reviewed or why Mrs May had agreed with them, or tried to stop them. 
Number 10 also refused to say why Mrs May as home secretary allowed al-Harith had been allowed to travel back to Syria in 2014. 
Mrs May’s deputy official spokesman said to each question: “It is an intelligence matter.” Jamal al-Harith 
“When his release was announced in very measured terms in 2004, pointing out the risks which remained with Guantanamo detainees, the Conservative MPs reacted by strongly criticising not the released but why it had taken so long. 
“The fact is that this was always a very difficult situation where any Government would have to balance proper concern for civil liberties with desire to protect our security, and we were likely to be attacked whatever course we took. 
“The reason it did take a long time for their release was precisely the anxiety over their true affiliations.” Follow Telegraph News
